In our experiment at ID15B, we have measured the temperature dependence of the structure factor at elevated pressures using a DAC setup. We have demonstrated the possibility to deeply supercool Te at pressures at least up to 0.9 GPa (9 kbar). While analysis is still ongoing, in Figure 2 we show preliminary results on the position of the first diffraction peak, ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 , as a function of the temperature, ğ‘‡, during three scans. The approximate pressure during each scan is shown in the legend. Although the changes in ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 are relatively small, the results are reproducible: the two scans at 0.7 GPa agree relatively well with each other, and both show somewhat lower ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 positions than the higher-pressure scan at 0.9 GPa, as expected. In comparison, Figure 3 below shows ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 as a function of ğ‘‡ at 0.0 GPa obtained in our previous work [1]; in this study, three scans were performed to demonstrate reproducibility.

Figure 3: ğ‘„ position of the center of the first diffraction peak, ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 , under ğ‘ƒ â‰ˆ 0, obtained in our previous work [1]. Three temperture scans were performed in this study, and the results agree with each other.
Comparing Figures 2 and 3, several observations can be made:

1. The ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 positions at elevated pressures (Figure 2) are significantly higher than those under ğ‘ƒ â‰ˆ 0 (Figure 3), as expected. 2. In all cases, ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 decreases with cooling. This is opposed normal liquid behavior but is consistent with the fact that liquid Te expands upon cooling [1], similar to water. 3. Upon cooling from 700 K to 600 K, the decrease in ğ‘„ ğ‘š1 at 0.7 GPa (from ~2.120 Ã… -1 to ~2.105 Ã… -1 ) is to a much lesser degree than the decrease at zero pressure (from ~2.08 Ã… -1 to ~2.03 Ã… -1 ). The degree of decrease is even less at 0.9 GPa (from ~2.130 Ã… -1 to ~2.120 Ã… -1 ). Because a larger degree of change is expected when approaching the critical point, this observation suggests that the LLCP is likely closer to zero pressure than it is to 0.7 GPa (cf. Figure 1). Given observation #3 above, it is important to explore the lower-pressure part of the phase diagram, ideally below 0.5 GPa. This will be the goal of future experiments.
